name: the online discussion room
postTitle: Artificial Intelligence in healthcare - what do you think?

comments.content: I worked in an ER and cant think of any situation where AI would have helped a patient

replies.content: I can't imagine it being that useful in its current stage for immediate issues, but I can see it being good for analyzing a patient's health and data over a long period of time to find issues.
That's good to know.  I appreciate having the opinion of someone in that's worked in an area that we are discussing

comments.content: I think it may have it's uses in the future but it shouldn't be the only option.  That a real human doctor should always have the final say

AI is good for early analysis of a person's symptoms and health status, but every person's case is different so it could be good as a tool to help make doctors and nurses more efficient, but not for the actual decisions regarding a person's care which should always be made by the doctors and their patients together.
Have you considered data privacy? AI can pose significant risks to patient data privacy.

replies.content: I think our data is safer with an AI, anyone in a medical center can see your chart even though its not allowed it is there

The data privacy thing has more to do with how businesses operate in general as opposed to being unique to AI or the healthcare industry. As it stands, it would not remotely surprise me if hospitals are actively selling our health data (whether it's legal or not).

comments.content: The wide acceptance of AI confuses and worries me at times.  I see people so easily using it without really questioning how it works.  I think in a medical scenario it may cause problems

replies.content: exactly, because medical professional may sometimes rely on the data provided by the AI

comments.content: As  person who just had a data breach with their information through their insurance provider this can happen just as easily without AI.
AI in healthcare will raise concerns especially, in cases where by it will be replacing  people's jobs

AI can also track a patient's health statistics over time, to help with long-term analysis of their health status so doctors can be more informed about any potential health risks or problems that may rise with the patient.
AI should be limited to being a tool to increase efficiency and accuracy, without us developing a total dependence that would cost job availability.

Just in general I think it's a bad idea.  I'm a cancer survivor.  I prefer to talk to a human about my medical issues.  I don't mind if a program is used in the background for certain things but I prefer human interaction and would find myself trusting my doctor much easier
Have you considered timeliness of diagnosis? AI contributes to more timely diagnoses in healthcare and can thus help to detect diseases at an early stage.

replies.content: it feels like using google or web md for a diagnosis.

I definitely thinks it's super useful in diagnoses. One of the few definitively good things about AI is that it's incredibly proficient at aggregating data and observing trends that humans would otherwise overlook.

comments.content: I'm not sure how AI would contribute with to a timely diagnosis.  Are you meaning that it would reach the final diagnosis quicker?
Efficiency and accuracy of diagnosis is one area where AI can definitely assist doctors but the final diagnosis should come down to the doctor and their actual experiences.
I hope it is cheaper and not a $200 dr visit

replies.content: Ha ha I agree.  We definitely should get a discount!  Healthcare costs are insane!

comments.content: Have you considered cost reduction? AI can reduce costs in healthcare by streamlining operations and reducing resource utilization.
